ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In this course I gained an appreciation both for various significant German language texts. In addition, I also learned and practiced skills regarding how to critically read and discuss these texts, ranging from class discussions to close reading papers.
I learned how to look at a complex German text carefully and how to analyze its stylistic, linguistic, and semantic features.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I thought the course had a very interesting range of texts, and I liked the chronological approach. However, one slightly irritating thing was the large variation in the size of the texts; some would be a few pages, others would be much, much more. As a result, budgeting time was different week by week. 
I also greatly appreciated the draft-based approach to the papers, because it gave me a good chance to practice my longer-form German writing and get constructive feedback.

Its well-structured and the instructor is very engaging. It could benefit from more instructor interventions and explanations, although the texts we read were too complicated for clear-cut explanations to be offered.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the virtual seminar form of the class worked. In addition, Irina made a point of using breakout rooms frequently, which I found to be an effective way to get discussion going, before meeting up again in a larger group.
The virtual format was quite engaging, much like the weekly spoken and written reflections.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course, but only if the student were really willing to engage with the texts and think about contextual themes. There was a lot of background knowledge that I didn't necessarily have coming into the class about German/European history that might have been helpful to know, but overall if you have a general interest in German and literature, it is a good course.
Absolutely! If your German is good enough and youre looking to improve even more, take it!
